@2:23 you say that Kevin's idea about knots was wrong, however - I would argue that he didn't have the language for quantum mechanics and the discrete packets of energy levels that define quantum mechanics when reducing them to their basic elements: Quarks -- and that is a special kind of knot in reality - you can try to pull two quarks apart, but the energy used in pulling them away from each other is enough to spawn the counter elements of the quarks so they are always paired. The unique aspect of knot theory is it may be useful in trying to describe "nuclear pasta" inside a neutron star -- different elements smooshed together into proton-electron=neutron mergers would produce loops based on the compression of threads of paths for existing protons and electrons to navigate. It could help describe the physical properties of compressed elements inside a neutron star's crust.

To be clear, Quipu/Khipu, the knot devices used by the Inca, predate Inca civilization and were invented by prior Andean civilization, which goes back much further then the Inca themselves. Additionally, Quipu-like devices were used to some degree by Mesoamerican civilizations as well. It's an obscure fact, but a 1746 text by Lorenzo Boturini Benaduci discusses hearing of them, called Nepohualtzintzin (the term is also used by some Neo-Aztec nationalists to describe an abbacus like device, though this is likely a hoax) via an informant in Tlaxcala, but Borturini sadly says he was not able to acquire an example himself. Perhaps even more notably, there is a 1579 account by Diego de Valadés which also describes such devices, again, used in Tlaxcala, and Valadés directly compares them to the Quipu devices recently encountered in Peru.

Hi @SciShow, one small error I noticed in the video: a pretzel is not actually considered a knot, because the two ends fuse with an existing length of dough, creating a tee intersection. A mathematical knot must be homeomorphic to the circle (that just means you can travel along it in a little ant-car, and you'll go along all portions of it without encountering any intersections, and come back to where you started). They would of course be very interesting objects to study in their own right, and probably someone has. Another related object is "links", which is just what it sounds like: a collection of one or more knots, possibly entangled with each other.

Colin Adams's "The Knot Book" (https://bookstore.ams.org/KNOT) is an EXCELLENT book on this topic, which I think is quite approachable for someone without any prior training, and has a wonderful conversational tone.

I cringe when I hear that the aether doesn't exist. The aether is space-time. We just don't want to call it that bc in the past some scientists had some details wrong...
Physicist Robert B. Laughlin wrote:

It is ironic that Einstein's most creative work, the general theory of relativity, should boil down to conceptualizing space as a medium when his original premise [in special relativity] was that no such medium existed [..] The word 'ether' has extremely negative connotations in theoretical physics because of its past association with opposition to relativity. This is unfortunate because, stripped of these connotations, it rather nicely captures the way most physicists actually think about the vacuum. . . . Relativity actually says nothing about the existence or nonexistence of matter pervading the universe, only that any such matter must have relativistic symmetry. [..] It turns out that such matter exists. About the time relativity was becoming accepted, studies of radioactivity began showing that the empty vacuum of space had spectroscopic structure similar to that of ordinary quantum solids and fluids. Subsequent studies with large particle accelerators have now led us to understand that space is more like a piece of window glass than ideal Newtonian emptiness. It is filled with 'stuff' that is normally transparent but can be made visible by hitting it sufficiently hard to knock out a part. The modern concept of the vacuum of space, confirmed every day by experiment, is a relativistic ether. But we do not call it this because it is taboo.

Summary of Cobble's Knot in Maniac McGee

"If the Wonders of the World hadn't stopped at seven, Cobble's Knot would have been number eight" (19.1).

Can a knot really be this special? Well, this one is is. It isn't just any knot;it's a knot with "more contortions, ins and outs, twists and turns and dips and doodles than the brain of Albert Einstein himself" (19.7).

So how does this knot, this knot that has "defeated all comers for years, including J.J. Thorndike, who grew up to be a magician, and Fingers Halloway, who grew up to be a pickpocket" (19.7) come to meet one Maniac Magee?

He's doing it cause Amanda asked (told?) him to. Let's hear from Amanda herself: "So you see, if you go up there and untie Cobble's Knot—which I know you can—you'll get your picture in the paper and you'll be the biggest hero ever around here and nooo-body'll mess with you then" (19.9).

Maniac manages to untangle the knot: "a huge roar went up, a volcano of cheers. Cobble's Knot was dead. Undone. Gone. It was nothing but string" (20.21). It's a huge celebration on Cobble's Corner, and yup, Maniac is the hero.

.....

Maniac takes off after the Encyclopedia A is destroyed because things haven't changed—Cobble's Knot hasn't fixed everything. Maniac (and Amanda) thinking that untangling the knot will make everything better shows their youth and inexperience.

Just A Knot After All

So a knot can't solve everything. Untangling a knot can't make people like you, though it may make lots of people cheer. Because, ultimately, a knot is a thing, and things can't change people. People change people.

One way of thinking about it is this: Cobble's Knot symbolizes all the tricky, knotty problems that come along with living in this tricky, knotty world. And being able to unravel a string knot doesn't mean you're ready to unravel the world.

I am particularly excited for the quantum computing leaps. Cause if we can simplify the paths and maybe program them in somehow, then the paths taken could form a coding language of there own. If you get enough of them you could program each atom as a specific path and then you could use each 'bit' of data to represent an element. You could describe the structure of molecules in only a few more bits than there are atoms in the molecule, probably plus a few to describe folding the molecule which could also be described as a knot in itself! DNA codes could be written in the same way! Instead of AGGGCTA, that whole sequence could be represented by a single bit! That could massively shrink data storage sizes and crack through the issues we're running up against where electrons are randomly jumping the gaps because we've shrunk the circuits so small that they don't even break a sweat from that tiny quantum tunnel.

Cool! Thanks for the episode on knots. My undergraduate thesis was on how much one of those identifying functions (a knot invariant) could change if a crossing was snipped and re-joined on the other side (like the enzyme does to the DNA). I actually got to contribute a little bit to the mathematics you described here. The best part was telling people who asked what my thesis was about that: “it’s (k)not theory.” To which they might reply: “So it’s applied math?”

I could take a small issue with your comment at 7:20 that "computers have not completely solved [the knot recognition problem]". Geometrization together with the JSJ decomposition in-principle is not only a solution, but a beautiful solution. Much of it has been implemented on computer and the algorithms are highly effective provided your knot does not have an insane number of crossings (like, say, over 100). Most of the algorithms are implemented in the software packages Regina and Snappea. The former was created by Ben Burton, the latter by Jeff Weeks, although there have been many contributors to both. The issue you consider later in the video -- knotted spheres in 4-space, this is a problem that (as far as we know) may be computationally infeasible, i.e. it may be provably-impossible to create algorithms that reliably distinguish different knots.
Interesting!  Thank you Hank, et. al.
